abstracts.cdata!:
This is an environmental assessment of
            the Haryana Water Resources Consolidation Project (WRCP).
            The project is involved with the irrigation of the Haryana
            area including the construction of various canals and pipe
            systems.  The following potential negative impacts are
            identified:  1) soil erosion mitigated by the proper design
            and layout of furrows, hillside terraces, and sprinkler
            systems; 2) waterlogging, leaching and salinization of soils
            mitigated by: a) water application regulation; b) an
            adequate drainage system c) use of lined canals or pipes; d)
            sprinkler or drip irrigation; e) periodic soil flushing; f)
            special crop cultivation; and g) nutrient replacement; 3)
            scouring of canals mitigated by system design; 4) clogging
            of canals by sediments and weeds mitigated by the design and
            management of canals, access provisions, and nutrient
            release reduction; 5) downstream impacts (water quality and
            quantity deterioration, sea water intrusion, and ground
            water contamination) mitigated by: a) improved water
            management, agricultural practices, and input controls; b)
            imposition of water quality criteria; c) reduction of
            takeoff; and c) recharge of coastal aquifers through
            injection wells; 6) wildlife and ecosystem effects
            (encroachment on sensitive areas, habitat alteration or
            destruction and impediments to wildlife movement) mitigated
            by project location, compensatory area establishment,
            animal rescue and relocation, and movement corridor
            provision; 7) dislocation of population mitigated by project
            location and a resettlement scheme; 8) water-related disease
            prevented by: a) the use of lined canals or pipes; b)
            avoidance of stagnant water; c) use of straight or slightly
            curving canals; d) gate installation; e) filling or draining
            of borrow pits; f) disease prophylaxis and treatment; g)
            wastewater treatment; and h) enforcement of waste water use
            standards; and 9) over-pumping of ground water mitigated by
            withdrawal limitations.  The report concludes that while
            direct environmental impacts from Haryana Irrigation
            Department activities are minor and can be dealt with
            through simple mitigation measures, there is a justifiable
            scope for regional environmental planning for water
            resources development using a multisector approach.
